---
title: "redis-ca-bytes.yml"
---

## High-level description
This YAML configuration file defines settings for a cache system using Redis as the backend. It includes specific configurations for enabling the cache, setting a Time-To-Live (TTL) value, and providing a CA certificate for secure Redis connections.

## Symbols

### `cache`
#### Description
The root configuration object for the cache system.

#### Internal Logic
- Enables the cache system
- Specifies Redis as the backend
- Sets a TTL of 60 seconds
- Includes nested Redis-specific configurations

### `cache.enabled`
#### Description
A boolean flag to enable or disable the cache system.

#### Inputs
| Name | Type | Description |
|:-----|:-----|:------------|
| enabled | boolean | When set to `true`, the cache system is enabled |

### `cache.backend`
#### Description
Specifies the cache backend to be used.

#### Inputs
| Name | Type | Description |
|:-----|:-----|:------------|
| backend | string | Set to `"redis"` to use Redis as the cache backend |

### `cache.ttl`
#### Description
Defines the Time-To-Live (TTL) for cached items.

#### Inputs
| Name | Type | Description |
|:-----|:-----|:------------|
| ttl | duration | Set to `"60s"`, indicating a 60-second TTL for cached items |

### `cache.redis`
#### Description
Contains Redis-specific configurations.

### `cache.redis.ca_cert_bytes`
#### Description
Provides the CA certificate for secure Redis connections in PEM format.

#### Inputs
| Name | Type | Description |
|:-----|:-----|:------------|
| ca_cert_bytes | string | A multi-line string containing the PEM-encoded CA certificate |

## Configuration
| Option | Type | Default | Description |
|:-------|:-----|:--------|:------------|
| cache.enabled | boolean | true | Enables the cache system |
| cache.backend | string | "redis" | Specifies Redis as the cache backend |
| cache.ttl | duration | "60s" | Sets the Time-To-Live for cached items |
| cache.redis.ca_cert_bytes | string | "pemblock" | Provides the CA certificate for secure Redis connections |

Note: The actual PEM-encoded certificate content is represented by the placeholder "pemblock" in this configuration file. In a real-world scenario, this would be replaced with the actual PEM-encoded CA certificate.
